qas.question: Who created the relational model of DBMS?
Instead of using links, how was information found in a relational model?
In what decade did computer hardware become able to handle a relational system?
What type of system in still prominent to this day?
What database language is the most prominent?
Who was falsely misrepresented as having created the relational model of DBMS?
How was information lost in a relational model?
What decade did computer hardware lose the ability to handle a relational system?
What type of system in rarely seen to this day?
What database language is now outlawed?

context: The relational model, first proposed in 1970 by <a0_0><b5_0>Edgar F. Codd<b5_0/><a0_0/>, departed from this tradition by insisting that applications should search for data <a1_0><b6_0>by content<b6_0/><a1_0/>, rather than by following links. The relational model employs sets of ledger-style tables, each used for a different type of entity. Only in the mid-<a2_0>1980s<a2_0/> did computing hardware become powerful enough to allow the wide deployment of relational systems (DBMSs plus applications). By the early <b7_0>1990s<b7_0/>, however, <a3_0><b8_0>relational systems<b8_0/><a3_0/> dominated in all large-scale data processing applications, and as of 2015[update] they remain dominant : IBM DB2, Oracle, MySQL and Microsoft SQL Server are the top DBMS. The dominant database language, standardised <a4_0><b9_0>SQL<b9_0/><a4_0/> for the relational model, has influenced database languages for other data models.[citation needed]
